questions.questionText: Select the reagents for this Aldol Condensation reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! This is an aldol condensation where benzaldehyde reacts with acetone under basic conditions (NaOH) to form 4-phenyl-3-buten-2-one, also known as benzalacetone.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. The aldol condensation requires an aldehyde and a base to deprotonate the alpha carbon of the ketone. Try again with the correct combination.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Aldol Condensation is a powerful C-C bond-forming reaction:

  • It occurs between two carbonyl compounds, at least one of which has an α-hydrogen
  • Base deprotonates the α-carbon to form an enolate
  • The enolate acts as a nucleophile and attacks the carbonyl carbon of the other molecule
  • Dehydration occurs to form an α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compound

The reaction can be either:

  1. A crossed aldol (between two different carbonyl compounds)
  2. A self-aldol (between identical carbonyl compounds)

In this example, the base (NaOH) deprotonates acetone to form an enolate, which attacks benzaldehyde. After dehydration, 4-phenyl-3-buten-2-one is formed with a new C=C bond.

questions.questionText: Select the reagents for this Diels-Alder reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! The Diels-Alder reaction between cyclopentadiene (diene) and ethylene (dienophile) forms norbornene, a bicyclic compound. This is a [4+2] cycloaddition reaction.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. The Diels-Alder reaction requires a diene and a dienophile. Try again with the right combination.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Diels-Alder reaction is a [4+2] cycloaddition between a conjugated diene and an alkene (dienophile):

  • Forms two new carbon-carbon σ bonds
  • Creates a six-membered ring
  • Occurs in a single concerted step
  • Does not require catalysts (though Lewis acids can accelerate it)

Key features of this reaction:

  1. It is stereospecific - the stereochemistry of the dienophile is preserved in the product
  2. It is governed by orbital symmetry (HOMO-LUMO interactions)
  3. Electron-donating groups on the diene and electron-withdrawing groups on the dienophile increase the reaction rate

In this example, cyclopentadiene acts as the diene (4π electrons) and ethylene as the dienophile (2π electrons), forming the bicyclic norbornene structure.

questions.questionText: Select the reagents for this Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! The Friedel-Crafts alkylation of benzene with chloroethane, catalyzed by aluminum chloride (a Lewis acid), produces ethylbenzene.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Friedel-Crafts alkylation requires an aromatic compound, an alkyl halide, and a Lewis acid catalyst. Try again!
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Friedel-Crafts Alkylation is an electrophilic aromatic substitution reaction:

  • Introduces an alkyl group onto an aromatic ring
  • Requires a Lewis acid catalyst (typically AlCl3)
  • Forms a carbocation intermediate that attacks the aromatic ring

Key considerations:

  1. Carbocation rearrangements can occur, leading to unexpected products
  2. The reaction works best with electron-rich arenes
  3. Cannot be performed on aromatic rings with strongly deactivating groups
  4. May lead to polyalkylation due to the activating effect of the first alkyl group

In this example, AlCl3 interacts with chloroethane to form an ethyl carbocation (CH3CH2+), which then attacks the electron-rich benzene ring to form ethylbenzene.

questions.questionText: Complete this Wittig reaction by selecting the correct reagents:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! The Wittig reaction between benzaldehyde and methyltriphenylphosphonium ylide forms styrene (an alkene) and triphenylphosphine oxide as a byproduct.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. The Wittig reaction converts aldehydes or ketones to alkenes using phosphonium ylides. Try again with the right combination of reagents.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Wittig Reaction is a valuable method for alkene synthesis:

  • Converts aldehydes or ketones to alkenes
  • Uses phosphonium ylides (R3P=CR'2) as reagents
  • Forms a new C=C bond at the position of the original C=O
  • Produces triphenylphosphine oxide as a byproduct

Mechanism steps:

  1. The ylide (a nucleophile) attacks the carbonyl carbon
  2. Formation of an oxaphosphetane intermediate (four-membered ring)
  3. Decomposition to the alkene and triphenylphosphine oxide

Advantages of the Wittig reaction:

  • Predictable regiochemistry - the new double bond forms at the exact position of the original carbonyl
  • Can be used with a wide variety of aldehydes and ketones
  • Mild conditions compared to some other alkene-forming reactions

In this example, the methylene ylide (Ph3P=CH2) reacts with benzaldehyde to form styrene and triphenylphosphine oxide.

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this hydroboration-oxidation reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! The hydroboration-oxidation of 1-butene using borane-THF followed by hydrogen peroxide/sodium hydroxide produces 1-butanol. This reaction shows anti-Markovnikov regioselectivity.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Hydroboration-oxidation requires a borane reagent followed by an oxidative workup. Try again with the correct reagents.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Hydroboration-Oxidation is a two-step process for converting alkenes to alcohols:

  • Step 1: Hydroboration - addition of B-H across the double bond
  • Step 2: Oxidation - the alkylborane is oxidized to an alcohol

Key features:

  1. Anti-Markovnikov orientation - hydrogen adds to the more substituted carbon
  2. Syn addition - B and H add to the same face of the double bond
  3. The overall transformation is the equivalent of anti-Markovnikov addition of water across a double bond
  4. High regioselectivity and stereoselectivity

Mechanism:

  • Borane adds to the less hindered end of the double bond (steric control)
  • The resulting trialkylborane is oxidized with H2O2/NaOH to give the alcohol with retention of configuration

In this example, 1-butene undergoes hydroboration with BH3·THF to form a trialkylborane. Subsequent oxidation with H2O2/NaOH gives 1-butanol as the major product.

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this Claisen condensation reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! The Claisen condensation between two molecules of ethyl acetate, catalyzed by sodium ethoxide, produces ethyl acetoacetate and ethanol.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. The Claisen condensation requires an ester with α-hydrogens and a strong base. Try again with the right combination.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Claisen Condensation is a carbon-carbon bond-forming reaction between two esters or an ester and a carbonyl compound:

  • Requires a strong base (typically an alkoxide)
  • At least one ester must have α-hydrogens
  • Forms a β-keto ester product
  • Results in acyl transfer from one molecule to another

Mechanism steps:

  1. Base removes an α-proton from the ester, forming an enolate
  2. The enolate attacks the carbonyl carbon of a second ester molecule
  3. Tetrahedral intermediate collapses, ejecting an alkoxide
  4. Acid workup protonates the product

Applications:

  • Provides access to β-dicarbonyl compounds
  • These products are versatile synthetic intermediates due to their acidic α-hydrogens
  • Can be followed by decarboxylation to yield ketones

In this example, two molecules of ethyl acetate undergo condensation with sodium ethoxide as the base, forming ethyl acetoacetate (a β-keto ester) and ethanol as a byproduct.

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this Heck reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! The Heck reaction between iodobenzene and styrene, catalyzed by palladium acetate with triethylamine as a base, produces trans-stilbene.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. The Heck reaction requires a palladium catalyst and a base to couple an aryl halide with an alkene. Try again with the right combination of reagents.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Heck Reaction is a palladium-catalyzed cross-coupling reaction:

  • Couples aryl or vinyl halides with alkenes
  • Forms a new C-C bond
  • Requires a palladium catalyst
  • Proceeds with retention of alkene configuration
  • Requires a base to neutralize the HX byproduct

Catalytic cycle:

  1. Oxidative addition of the aryl/vinyl halide to Pd(0)
  2. Alkene coordination and insertion
  3. β-hydride elimination to form the product
  4. Reductive elimination of HX and regeneration of the Pd(0) catalyst

Key features:

  • Tolerates many functional groups
  • Generally gives trans products
  • Often uses phosphine ligands to stabilize Pd intermediates
  • Can be performed under relatively mild conditions

In this example, iodobenzene couples with styrene in the presence of Pd(OAc)2 and triethylamine to yield trans-stilbene. The reaction typically proceeds with high stereoselectivity, favoring the trans isomer.

questions.questionText: Complete this Michael addition reaction by selecting the correct reagents:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! This Michael addition involves benzylacetone (as the nucleophile) adding to ethyl acrylate (the Michael acceptor) catalyzed by sodium methoxide, forming ethyl 4-oxo-6-phenylhexanoate.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Michael addition requires a nucleophile (typically an enolate), an α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compound, and a base catalyst. Try again with the correct combination.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Michael Addition is a conjugate addition reaction:

  • Involves the addition of a nucleophile to the β position of an α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compound
  • The nucleophile (Michael donor) is typically an enolate or other stabilized carbanion
  • The electrophile (Michael acceptor) is an α,β-unsaturated carbonyl or related system
  • Results in 1,4-addition rather than 1,2-addition

Mechanism:

  1. Base deprotonates the Michael donor to form an enolate
  2. The enolate attacks the β-carbon of the Michael acceptor
  3. Protonation of the resulting enolate generates the final product

Key features:

  • Forms new carbon-carbon bonds
  • Creates 1,5-dicarbonyl compounds which are versatile synthetic intermediates
  • Can be performed under mild conditions
  • Works with a variety of nucleophiles including enolates, amines, thiols, and others

In this example, sodium methoxide deprotonates benzylacetone to form an enolate, which then attacks the β-carbon of ethyl acrylate. Protonation of the resulting enolate gives ethyl 4-oxo-6-phenylhexanoate.

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this alcohol oxidation reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! Pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC) oxidizes cyclohexanol (a secondary alcohol) to cyclohexanone (a ketone). PCC is a mild and selective oxidizing agent.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Oxidation of secondary alcohols to ketones requires an appropriate oxidizing agent. Try again with the correct combination.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Oxidation of Secondary Alcohols converts them to ketones:

  • Various oxidizing agents can be used with different selectivity and reactivity profiles
  • PCC (Pyridinium Chlorochromate) is a mild oxidant that selectively oxidizes alcohols
  • Primary alcohols → aldehydes
  • Secondary alcohols → ketones
  • PCC typically doesn't oxidize aldehydes further to carboxylic acids

Key features of PCC oxidation:

  1. Mild reaction conditions (typically in dichloromethane at room temperature)
  2. Good selectivity for alcohol oxidation
  3. Minimal overoxidation or side reactions
  4. Particularly useful for molecules with sensitive functional groups

Mechanism:

  • The alcohol reacts with the Cr(VI) species
  • Chromate ester intermediate forms
  • Hydride transfer from the α-carbon to chromium
  • Reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(IV)
  • Formation of the carbonyl compound

In this example, cyclohexanol is oxidized to cyclohexanone using PCC, with the oxidation state of chromium being reduced in the process.

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this ketone reduction reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! Sodium borohydride (NaBH4) reduces 4-tert-butylcyclohexanone to 4-tert-butylcyclohexanol. This reaction primarily gives the more stable equatorial alcohol.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Reduction of ketones to alcohols requires a suitable reducing agent. Try again with the correct combination.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Reduction of Ketones converts them to secondary alcohols:

  • Sodium borohydride (NaBH4) is a common, mild reducing agent
  • It selectively reduces aldehydes and ketones to alcohols
  • Does not usually reduce esters, carboxylic acids, or amides
  • Works under mild conditions (typically in methanol or ethanol at room temperature)

Stereochemical considerations:

  1. In cyclic systems, the hydride typically approaches from the less hindered face
  2. For 4-tert-butylcyclohexanone, the tert-butyl group blocks one face of the molecule
  3. This results in preferential formation of the isomer with the OH group equatorial
  4. The product distribution is influenced by steric and stereoelectronic effects

Mechanism:

  • Hydride transfer from borohydride to the carbonyl carbon
  • Formation of an alkoxide intermediate
  • Protonation during workup to give the alcohol product

In this reaction, sodium borohydride reduces 4-tert-butylcyclohexanone to give 4-tert-butylcyclohexanol, predominantly as the equatorial alcohol isomer due to the directing effect of the bulky tert-butyl group.
